author: @krishnaik06
text: Guys at 3:34 just a small update The p-value is not interpreted as a probability that the null hypothesis is true.   It is the probability of observing a value of the test statistic that is as or more extreme than what was observed in the sample, assuming the null hypothesis is true. author: @kylesnodgrass1
text: Finally a video that explained what is happening. I managed to work out a definition from summarising your video.... thank you.  95% of all results will be average. However, 5% or less would be classified as extraordinary. Therefore, if your experiment gave results which are 5% or less than likely to occur on average, the independent variable you have manipulated is significant, because it changed the results from average to extraordinary.
